/* Economic policies */ The Nazis did initially support corporatism but abandoned support of it shortly after gaining power because they thought in legalized class division rather unifying the nation
The Nazis abandoned official endorsement of corporatism shortly after gaining power, they claimed it legitimized class divisions and thus prevented the biological unity of the German nation
Made correction to intro as mentioned in on the discussion board
Hopefully that will satisfy all involved, I cited one of the leading global scholars of international relations, comparative politics, and foreign policy so hopefully that should suffice

why are some here intent in preventing mention of the fascist disdain for individualism (or the same thing, support for collectivism)?
/* Definitions */ deleted sentence "some feel fascism is..." because it has no citation, does not say who the 'some' are, and contradicts the information in the preceding and following paragraphs.
Removed point claiming that fascism opposed socialism, fascism opposed non-nationalist and class-conflict causing socialism, Mussolini claimed that its economic system could be considered socialist
Mentioning that fascism is nationalist and collectivist is double-speaking the same thing. Their collectivism was based on national unity, a national form of collectism IS nationalism.
/* National corporatism, national socialism and national syndicalism */ Moved point from the intro to here
Removing a synthesis of sources, the one quote by Hitler on corporatism was an important addition however, but is misplaced and the user was not aware that Nazism later rejected corporatism.
"radical, authoritarian and nationalist" is not accurate to what the references were meaning, the three words are not separate, they are connected together
redundant, changing so there can be no dispute
doesnt cover one of the most essential aspects ..collectivism
Covers it all, and if there are exceptions they fall under that too

rev.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contributions/208.82.154.6|208.82.154.6]] to last revision by PhilLiberty ([[WP:HG|HG]])
just because some other groups are collectivist, doesn't mean fascism isn't collectivist as well. I'm attaching as reliable source for this.
look up "collectivism" It does not just refer to Fascist national unity ("Nationalism") but to many groups - including Communist and Anarchist and more
No such thing as a non-collectivist fascist. The collectivism is even symbolized in the fascist symbol pictured. It's essential to fascism.
more aspects would be good, I suppose, but too many fascists historically appear to have been quite non-collectivist
the definition in this article is too vague. Needs more aspects, such as the collectivist nature which well established in the sources.
